abstract.text: An abstract superclass for items that you can add to a bar that appears at the bottom of the screen.

inlineContent.text: Items on a bar behave in a way similar to buttons (instances of
). They have a title, image, action, and target. You can also enable and disable an item on a bar.
You can customize the image to represent the item, and the position of the image, using
You can also specify a custom image and position to use in landscape orientation when using the iPhone appearance idiom using
respectively. In addition, you can customize the titleâ€™s text attributes using
, either for a single item, or for all items by using the appearance proxy (for example,

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A specialized button for placement on a toolbar, navigation bar, or shortcuts bar.
A group of one or more bar button items for placement on a navigation bar or shortcuts bar.
An abstract superclass for items that you can add to a bar that appears at the bottom of the screen.
The image used to represent the item.
The image inset or outset for each edge.
Initializes the bar item to its default state.
Creates a bar item from data in an unarchiver.
A Boolean value indicating whether the item is enabled.
The image to use to represent the item in landscape orientation when using the iPhone appearance idiom.
The image inset or outset for each edge of the image in landscape orientation when using the iPhone appearance idiom.
The image to display for users who are blind or have low vision.
The insets to apply to the bar itemâ€™s large image when displaying the image in an assistive UI.
Sets the titleâ€™s text attributes for a given control state.
The bar itemâ€™s tag, an app-supplied integer that you can use to identify bar item objects in your app.
The title displayed on the item.
Returns the titleâ€™s text attributes for a given control state.
A set of methods for defining the positioning of bars in iOS apps.
A set of methods that support the positioning of a bar that conforms to the
protocol.
A control that executes your custom code in response to user interactions.
Navigational controls that display in a bar along the top of the screen, usually in conjunction with a navigation controller.
A specialized view for receiving search-related information from the user.
A control that displays one or more buttons in a tab bar for selecting between different subtasks, views, or modes in an app.
An object that describes an item in a tab bar.
A control that displays one or more buttons along the bottom edge of your interface.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
